pathway_description: Direct Air Capture (DAC) refers to a family of technologies that use a chemical approach to capture CO2 from ambient air and generate a concentrated stream of CO2 for storage. We assume here that captured CO2 is not used for enhanced oil recovery (EOR).

elements.name: inj_co2
elements.comments: The mass of CO2 injected for geologic storage, or used as an input for another storage process (e.g. mineralization in concrete), can be measured directly as a metered output from the DAC system, and a metered input to the storage system. It can also be checked for consistency against operational data from the CO2 capture system system.

elements.name: store_leak
elements.comments: The mass of CO2 that escapes from the storage system must include a consideration of poth observed leakage and potential future leakage. For terrestrial geologic storage, fugitive emissions can be directly monitored during and after the injection period,, though this is more challenging for subseafloor reservoirs. If geologic storage results in functionally stable form on a short timescale — for example, via subsurface mineralization — fugitive emissions associated with the full lifetime of storage may be estimated based on direct observations of the storage reservoir. If, however, the integrity of geologic storage requires ongoing monitoring and maintenance, for example with the injection of supercritical CO2, the potential for future fugitive emissions must be modeled. For alternative storage systems, like mineralization in concrete, it is possible to directly measure the conversion of input CO2 into a functionally stable form and therefore the fugitive emissions from the storage system.

elements.name: energy_co2
elements.comments: The emissions associated with energy use for the process. This component should be estimated based on an assessment of lifecycle emissions for the specific electricity or energy sources consumed on-site.

elements.name: mat_co2
elements.comments: The embodied emissions (including transport) of any materials consumed during operation, like mineral feedstocks or solvents, can be estimated based on a lifecycle assessment of the consumed material. The embodied emissions of equipment and project infrastructure must also be considered. This would include manufacturing and transportation-related emissions for equipment and infrastructure, like a calciner or air contactor, that is not consumed as part of the project operation. Equipment emissions should be amortized over the expected carbon removal over the lifetime of the equipment.

elements.name: stor_maint
elements.comments: If storage results in a functionally stable form of CO2 on a short timescale — for example, via subsurface mineralization or mineralization in concrete — demonstration that the stable form has been achieved is enough to establish permanence. If, however, the integrity of storage requires ongoing monitoring and maintenance — for example with the injection of supercritical CO2 — an evaluation of permanence claims must consider the monitoring and maintenance plan, as well as any applicable regulatory structure that assigns ongoing liability for storage integrity. One important consideration is whether or not there is a track record of sufficient administrative capacity to guarantee execution of monitoring, and maintenance, and liability arrangements.

elements.name: ops
elements.comments: The basis of any rigorous evaluation of what a carbon removal project has achieved is clarity around a project's operations. This includes (1) transparent operations and the ability for external parties to see the process unfolding, (2) auditable operation records that can be cross-checked against carbon removal claims, (3) transparent protocols around how carbon management outcomes are quantified if such claims are being made by the project, and (4) an auditable — and preferably public —registry that ensures against double-counting of carbon removal benefits.

pathway_description: Biomass with carbon removal and storage (BiCRS) uses plants or algae to remove CO2 from the atmsophere via photsynthesis, and transforms that biomass (e.g. via pyrolysis) to achieve long-term storage.

elements.name: bio_added
elements.comments: The mass of biomass material injected for geologic storage — or used as an input for another storage process — can be measured directly as a metered output from the biomass transformation system (e.g. a pyrolyzer) and as a metered input to the storage system, and converted to carbon using a default carbon content factor. This quantity can also be checked for consistency against the measured mass of biomass feedstock, and operational data from the biomass transformation system.

elements.name: stor_leak
elements.comments: For terrestrial geologic storage, fugitive emissions (or migrating bio-oil) can be directly monitored during and after the injection period, though this would be more challenging for subseafloor reservoirs. If geologic storage results in functionally stable form on a short timescale — for example, via subsurface mineralization of CO2 or demonstration that injected bio-oil will not break down into CO2 and biomethane under subsurface conditions  — fugitive emissions associated with the full lifetime of storage may be estimated based on direct observations of the storage reservoir. If however the integrity of geologic storage requires ongoing monitoring and maintenance, for example if the degradation dynamics of bio-oil are unknown under storage conditions, the potential for future fugitive emissions must be modeled.

elements.name: feed_stor
elements.comments: While nearly all biomass carbon eventually makes its way back to the atmosphere, the effective drawdown from BiCRS occurs when the CO2 would otherwise have ended up in the atmosphere. If the counterfactual fate of the biomass feedstock would have resulted in medium-to-long term carbon storage — for example in landfills, in slow degrading environments, or in soils — the mass of stored carbon in the counterfactual does not count as additional carbon removal until counterfactual emissions would have occurred.

elements.name: feed_current
elements.comments: If a biomass feedstock currently serves a function that will need to be replaced if used for BiCRS, any emissions associated with the replacement must be considered.  For example, if agricultural waste is currently used as animal feed or left on the fields to contribute to nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium in soils, using that agricultural waste for BiCRS would result in new demand for feed or fertilizer, respectively. Current feedstock uses can be evaluated on a project-by-project basis, and the carbon impact of replacements can be estimated via lifecycle assessments.

elements.name: LUC_indirect
elements.comments: Any emissions associated with indirect land use change as a result of feedstock demand must be considered. For example, paying farmers for agricultural waste will likely increase the profitability of their operations, and could result in increased acres planted. Directly growing energy crops or creating plantations may displace food production onto other lands and contribute to deforestation. Conversely, the creation of markets for forestry residues could help reduce the rate of conversion of forest systems to agricultural use, however to be conservative, this potential positive impact should not be counted toward the quantified carbon removal outcome. Estimating indirect land use change resulting from BiCRS feedstock demand will likely require careful economic modeling.
elements.notes: Uncertainty is low for agricultural or woody biomass waste, Medium to High for dedicated energy crops or plantations

elements.name: energy_co2
elements.comments: The emissions associated with energy use for the process should be estimated based on an assessment of lifecycle emissions for the specific electricity or energy sources consumed by the project.

elements.name: mat_co2
elements.comments: The embodied emissions (including transport) of any materials consumed during operation, like biomass feedstock, can be estimated based on a lifecycle assessment of the consumed material. The embodied emissions of equipment and project infrastructure must also be considered. This would include manufacturing and transportation-related emissions for equipment and infrastructure, like a pyrolyzer, that is not consumed as part of the project operation. Equipment and infrastructure emissions should be amortized over the carbon removal expected to take place over the lifetime of the equipment.

elements.name: stor_maint
elements.comments: If the integrity of geologic storage requires ongoing monitoring and maintenance — for example with the injection of supercritical CO2 — a clear plan must be presented and backed up by a regulatory structure that assigns liability for storage integrity. One important consideration is whether or not there is a track record of sufficient administrative capacity to guarantee execution of monitoring and maintenance plans.

elements.name: ops
elements.comments: The basis of any rigorous evaluation of what a carbon removal project has achieved is clarity around a project's operations. This includes (1) transparent operations and the ability for external parties to see the process unfolding, (2) auditable operation records that can be cross-checked against carbon removal claims, (3) transparent protocols around how carbon management outcomes are quantified if such claims are being made by the project, and (4) an auditable — and preferably public —registry that ensures against double-counting of carbon removal benefits.

pathway_description: Enhanced weathering (EW) is a process that aims to accellerate the natural weathering of rocks by speeding up the chemical reactions between rocks, water and air. Here, we specifically consider EW facilitated by spreading finely ground rock on agricultural soils.

elements.name: rock_opt
elements.comments: Assuming full dissolution of the applied rock, it is possible to calculate the optimum atmospheric removal assuming full dissolution. Optimum drawdown depends on rock composition, particle size, kinetics, and applied volumes. It is possible to directly analyze rock composition, which is critical not only for carbon accounting, but also for tracking other ecosystem and agricultural impacts. Applied volume can be confirmed via an audit of operational records.

elements.name: nwp
elements.comments: The rate of rock weathering depends on factors including particle size, soil type, ambient temperature, precipitation, and irrigation. While most feedstock dissolution potential will ultimately be realized, the effective drawdown from EW occurs when the CO2 is actually removed from the atmosphere. The measurement of weathering rates — and by extension the fraction of the mineral feedstock that remains after a given period of time — is an area of active innovation. Existing approaches include measuring temporally granular changes to pH and dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC), and tracking changes in the concentration of tracer elements which originate in the applied mineral and persist in the soil after rock weathering.

elements.name: alk_loss
elements.comments: Mineral weathering results in atmospheric CO2 drawdown when acid reacts with the applied mineral, thereby increasing the alkalinity of soil pore water and increasing its capacity to store atmospheric CO2. Non-CO2 sources of acidity in the soil may react with the resulting alkalinity, reducing total CO2 drawdown. These sources of acid may include protons associated with mineral and organic surfaces, denitrification, or sulfide oxidation.

elements.name: min_sec
elements.comments: Secondary mineral formation – such as clays that counteract the alkalinity increase associated with weathering – depends on the type of primary mineral dissolving as well as the local climate and biota present. Since secondary mineral formation results in less atmospheric carbon removal, it is important to characterize via soil mineralogy techniques like x-ray diffraction in order to accurately determine the total amount of carbon removed from that atmosphere.

elements.name: evasion
elements.comments: The additional flux of dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) from the site of application into regional groundwater systems represents captured CO2. The longer-term fate of this DIC is hard to precisely estimate. Groundwater can spend days to centuries in the ground before being discharged to streams. Once in surface waters, outgassing (evasion) might occur, for example as a result of shifts in pH.  The long time-scale of this process makes it difficult to study directly, but regional models may inform evasion estimates.

elements.name: soil_c
elements.comments: Mineral addition to soils could have a diversity of impacts on soil carbon, including via changes to plant or microbial productivity. There has been relatively limited research on this topic to-date, and we recommend that these carbon cycle impacts should not be used to counterbalance project lifecycle emissions nor counted as additional sequestration due to the complexity and impermanence of soil carbon storage.

elements.name: energy_co2
elements.comments: The emissions associated with energy use for the process should be estimated based on an assessment of lifecycle emissions for the specific electricity or energy sources consumed by the project.

elements.name: mat_co2
elements.comments: The embodied emissions of any materials consumed during operation, like mineral feedstocks, can be estimated based on a cradle-to-grave lifecycle assessment of the material input. The embodied emissions of non-consumed project equipment and infrastructure must also be considered, amortized over the expected lifetime of operation. There are not yet consistent best practices around whether or how to account for the embodied emissions of equipment or infrastructure that is used but not owned by the project. Transparency around these boundary assumptions, as well as the data sources and associated uncertainties across the board, is necessary for LCA consistency and comparability.

elements.name: lime_replace
elements.comments: In agricultural contexts, the application of a weathering mineral might substitute for the application of lime, thereby displacing the lifecycle emissions (or carbon drawdown) associated with the lime application. Any emissions impact associated with the displaced agricultural lime use could thus potentially counterbalance life cycle emissions of applying the weathering mineral. Lime emissions could be estimated based on data about prior usage on the parcel of land in question, or through general best practices for the region and crop type.

elements.name: fert_reduce
elements.comments: Applied mineral may contain trace amounts of phosphorus and potassium, which could potentially reduce fertilizer requirements compared to conventional liming approaches.

elements.name: carb_surf
elements.comments: The formation of surficial carbonates depends on the type of primary mineral dissolving, carbonate saturation state, and other local environmental conditions. Although surficial carbonates have complex seasonal dynamics of dissolution and reprecipitation, there is a high likelihood of long-term permanence.

elements.name: tau_dic
elements.comments: The concept of ocean DIC lifetime is a well-established theory and is accepted within the community to lie somewhere between 10,000-100,000 years. [TK: permanence of surficial carbonates.]

elements.comments: The basis of any rigorous evaluation of what a carbon removal project has achieved is clarity around a project's operations. This includes (1) transparent operations and the ability for external parties to see the process unfolding, (2) auditable operation records that can be cross-checked against carbon removal claims, (3) transparent protocols around how carbon management outcomes are quantified if such claims are being made by the project, and (4) an auditable — and preferably public —registry that ensures against double-counting of carbon removal benefits.

pathway_description: Terrestrial Biomass Sinking uses plants or algae to remove CO2 from the atmsophere via photsynthesis, and sinks that biomass into the deep ocean to achieve long-term carbon storage.

elements.name: terr_added
elements.comments: The mass of biomass carbon that is deployed to be sunk into the ocean for storage can be measured directly in terms of the mass of material bailed or used in buoys, and converted to carbon using a default carbon content factor. This quantity can also be checked for consistency against operational data like purchase records.

elements.name: nsad
elements.comments: Some fraction of the deployed biomass may not successfully sink to the ocean floor or might not sink at suitable depth for long-term storage. This could be a result of biomass being shed during the sinking process, which could be modeled as a function of biomass type and sinking configuration based on field observations. For biomass that sinks after some period of floating in the open ocean (e.g. biomass-based buoys), the possibility that biomass may end up being beached or sinking in areas that do not result in permanent storage (e.g. shallow waters or areas of upwelling) must also be considered. Existing surface ocean transport models could be validated based on GPS-based observational data.
elements.notes: The potential impact of the non-sunk fraction on total carbon sequestration is low for projects doing direct biomass sinking, but medium to high for projects with undirected sinking (e.g. projects using terrestrial biomass to make floating buoy platforms for kelp).

elements.name: terr_stor
elements.comments: While nearly all biomass carbon eventually makes its way back to the atmosphere, the effective drawdown from biomass sinking occurs when the CO2 would otherwise have ended up in the atmosphere. If the counterfactual fate of the biomass feedstock would have resulted in medium-to-long term carbon storage — for example in landfills, in slow degrading environments, or in soils — the mass of stored carbon in the counterfactual does not count as additional carbon removal until counterfactual emissions would have occurred.

elements.name: terr_current
elements.comments: If a biomass feedstock currently serves a function that will need to be replaced if used for sinking, any emissions associated with the replacement must be considered.  For example, if agricultural waste is currently used as animal feed or left on the fields to contribute to nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium in soils, using that agricultural waste for sinking would result in new demand for feed or fertilizer, respectively. Current feedstock uses can be evaluated on a project-by-project basis, and the carbon impact of replacements can be estimated via lifecycle assessments.

For example, paying farmers for agricultural waste will likely increase the profitability of their operations, and could result in increased acres planted. Estimating indirect land use change resulting from feedstock demand will likely require careful economic modeling.

elements.comments: This component should be based on an assessment of lifecycle emissions of the specific electricity or energy sources consumed by the project.

The embodied emissions of non-consumed project equipment and infrastructure must also be considered, amortized over the expected lifetime of operation. There are not yet consistent best practices around whether or how to account for the embodied emissions of equipment or infrastructure that is used but not owned by the project. Transparency around these boundary assumptions, as well as the data sources and associated uncertainties across the board, is necessary for LCA consistency and comparability.

elements.name: t_recirculation
elements.comments: From a carbon management perspective, it is conservative to assume that all sunk biomass is remineralized, and that ocean circulation and currents will eventually return the CO2 back to the surface ocean, where it will be brought into equilibrium with the atmosphere. The estimated timescale of this ventilation is dependent on the location of sinking and depth achieved, which must be characterized at the project level, but can be informed by models.
elements.notes: The uncertainty associated with time to recirculation is dependent on how well sinking location is known and specified.

pathway_description: Ocean Biomass Sinking uses macroalge to remove CO2 from surface ocean, which in turn enhances the ability of the surface ocean to drawdown atmospheric CO2. The biomass is sunk into the deep ocean to achieve long-term carbon storage. Here, we specifically consider approaches that do not involve harvesting the ocean biomass before sinking it.

elements.name: kelp_grown
elements.comments: The mass of kelp grown can be converted to carbon using a default carbon content factor. For systems that involve an ocean biomass harvesting step, biomass can be measured directly before sinking. For systems that do not involve a kelp harvesting step, yield models may be developed as a function of species and strain, macro- and micronutrient availability, episodic mortality events like disease & storms, and other environmental factors that affect kelp growth. These models must be calibrated based on observational data, which could be derived from direct sampling and weighing, or from indirect measures from conjoined observational buoys (e.g. with instruments pointed at growing kelp).

elements.name: nsad
elements.comments: Some fraction of the deployed biomass may not successfully sink to the ocean floor or might not sink at suitable depth for long-term storage. This could be a result of biomass being shed during the sinking process, which could be modeled as a function of biomass type and sinking configuration based on field observations. For biomass that sinks after some period of floating in the open ocean (e.g. biomass-based buoys), the possibility that biomass may end up being beached or sinking in areas that do not result in permanent storage (e.g. shallow waters or areas of upwelling) must also be considered. Existing surface ocean transport models could be validated based on GPS-based observational data.

elements.name: comp
elements.comments: Kelp growth could have secondary effects on phytoplankton carbon uptake, including via nutrient depletion and canopy shading. This is an important factor to consider both in relation to broader ecosystem impacts and for quantifying carbon management outcomes. While only a fraction of the carbon removed by biological activity in the surface ocean may result in permanent carbon storage, we recommend a conservative stance of counting any decrease in surface ocean productivity against estimates of carbon removal achieved.

elements.name: dic_deep
elements.comments: Any carbon absorbed by kelp which comes from deeper waters rather than surface waters would reduce near-term (decades to centuries) atmospheric drawdown. Berger et al 2022 estimated that this could result in a ~25% reduction in net carbon removal, though that is only a single estimate in a meeting abstract. It is unclear what the best approach to directly measure this might be, and we may have to rely on models.

There are not yet consistent best practices around whether or how to account for the embodied emissions of equipment or infrastructure that is used but not owned by the project. Transparency around these boundary assumptions, as well as the data sources and associated uncertainties across the board, is necessary for LCA consistency and comparability.

pathway_description: Ocean alkalinity enhancement (OAE) adds alkalinity into the surface ocean to enhance its ability to uptake and store atmospheric CO2. Here, we specifically consider OAE that is facilitated by electrochemical separation that removes acidity from seawater to enhance ocean alkalinity.

elements.name: alk_add
elements.comments: Assuming full conversion of alkalinity into dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) from atmospheric CO2, this can be calculated based on the measured addition of NaOH or other alkalinity to the oceans.

elements.name: carb
elements.comments: Environmental conditions and alkalinity addition dynamics (e.g. rate of point source additions) result in different fractions of carbonate (HCO3-) versus bicarbonate (HCO3-). This is important to characterize as the uptake of atmospheric CO2 is reduced with the presence of more carbonate in the water. Overall CO2 uptake efficiency can be estimated using seawater chemistry modeling software and the equation presented in Renforth & Henderson (2017). These estimates could also be validated by measurements of bicarbonate concentrations or total alkalinity in the water column.

elements.name: sec_precip
elements.comments: Secondary precipitation of calcium carbonate (CaCO3) may occur abiotically if alkalinity concentrations are too high. This is important to characterize as this precipitation results in CO2 outgassing. Abiotic precipitation can be minimized by ensuring rapid dispersal relative to the rate of alkalinity addition. Sampling total alkalinity near the dispersal point can help quantitatively determine the extent to which alkalinity is lost due to precipitation.

elements.name: calc
elements.comments: Since calcification releases CO2 as a by-product, any changes to the rate of biotic calcification in response to alkalinity additions to the surface ocean must be considered. Shifts in biotic calcification rates could  occur in both coastal and open ocean waters, and could be tracked by measuring changes in total alkalinity over time and by sampling the water column to study changes in calcifier populations. In practice, quantifying the biotic calcification response to alkalinity addition may pose significant spatial and temporal challenges.

elements.name: poc
elements.comments: Additional formation of dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) as a result of alkalinity addition could lead to more particulate organic carbon (POC) formation in the surface ocean. This effect could be quite small if plankton communities are primarily limited by nutrient availability rather than DIC availability. However, it is possible for organisms to change their carbon-to-nutrient consumption ratios in response to changing environments which could result in a shift toward increased carbon drawdown in the surface ocean. Because only a small fraction of this increased drawdown would result in permanent carbon storage in the deep ocean, we conservatively recommend this not be counted as additional sequestration or used to counterbalance project lifecycle emissions.

elements.name: asg
elements.comments: Atmospheric uptake is reduced if alkalinity is transferred to the deep ocean before either increasing the uptake of atmospheric CO₂ or decreasing the outgassing of CO₂ to the atmosphere. The precise dispersal of alkalinity and associated efficiency of air-sea gas exchange is dependent on the location and timing of alkalinity deployment, and is hard to directly observe. In-situ measurements can potentially track post-deployment changes in pCO2, pH and dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) to help validate models of plume dispersal and atmospheric CO2 drawdown, though the sensitivity and cost of these sensors may be a challenge.

elements.name: acid_return
elements.comments: Any source of acid from the process that ultimately reaches the ocean or interacts with terrestrial carbonates prior to being neutralized will counteract claimed alkalinity enhancement. At the project level, it's possible to ascertain the likely end fate of produced acid using operational records. As this solution scales, acid disposal may become more of a challenge.

The embodied emissions of non-consumed project equipment and infrastructure must also be considered, amortized over the expected lifetime of operation. Transparency around these boundary assumptions, as well as the data sources and associated uncertainties across the board, is necessary for LCA consistency and comparability.

Sampling total alkalinity near the dispersal point can help quantitatively determine the extent to which alkalinity is lost due to precipitation.

elements.name: calc
elements.comments: Since calcification releases CO2 as a by-product, any changes to the rate of biotic calcification in response to alkalinity additions to the surface ocean must be considered. Shifts in biotic calcification rates could  occur in both coastal and open ocean waters, and could be tracked by measuring changes in total alkalinity over time and by sampling the water column to study changes in calcifier populations. In practice, quantifying the biotic calcification response to alkalinity addition may pose significant spatial and temporal challenges.

elements.name: poc
elements.comments: Additional formation of dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) as a result of alkalinity addition could lead to more particulate organic carbon (POC) formation in the surface ocean. This effect could be quite small if plankton communities are primarily limited by nutrient availability rather than DIC availability. However, it is possible for organisms to change their carbon-to-nutrient consumption ratios in response to changing environments which could result in a shift toward increased carbon drawdown in the surface ocean. Because only a small fraction of this increased drawdown would result in permanent carbon storage in the deep ocean, we conservatively recommend this not be counted as additional sequestration or used to counterbalance project lifecycle emissions.

elements.name: asg
elements.comments: Atmospheric uptake is reduced if alkalinity is transferred to the deep ocean before either increasing the uptake of atmospheric CO₂ or decreasing the outgassing of CO₂ to the atmosphere. The precise dispersal of alkalinity and associated efficiency of air-sea gas exchange is dependent on the location and timing of alkalinity deployment, and is hard to directly observe. In-situ measurements can potentially track post-deployment changes in pCO2, pH and dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) to help validate models of plume dispersal and atmospheric CO2 drawdown, though the sensitivity and cost of these sensors may be a challenge.

elements.name: energy_co2
elements.comments: This component should be based on an assessment of lifecycle emissions of the specific electricity or energy sources consumed by the project.

elements.name: mat_co2
elements.comments: The embodied emissions of any materials consumed during operation, like mineral feedstocks, can be estimated based on a cradle-to-grave lifecycle assessment of the material input. The embodied emissions of non-consumed project equipment and infrastructure must also be considered, amortized over the expected lifetime of operation. There are not yet consistent best practices around whether or how to account for the embodied emissions of equipment or infrastructure that is used but not owned by the project. Transparency around these boundary assumptions, as well as the data sources and associated uncertainties across the board, is necessary for LCA consistency and comparability.

elements.name: tau_dic
elements.comments: The concept of ocean dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) lifetime is well-established and is accepted within the community to lie somewhere between 10,000-100,000 years.

elements.name: ops
elements.comments: The basis of any rigorous evaluation of what a carbon removal project has achieved is clarity around a project's operations. This includes (1) transparent operations and the ability for external parties to see the process unfolding, (2) auditable operation records that can be cross-checked against carbon removal claims, (3) transparent protocols around how carbon management outcomes are quantified if such claims are being made by the project, and (4) an auditable — and preferably public —registry that ensures against double-counting of carbon removal benefits.
